Quotes: 
1) "Persons with MS (N = 183) with cognitive concerns were randomly assigned to either the 8-week MAPSS-MS intervention or usual care plus freely available computer games."
2) "The Perceived Deficits Questionnaire19 was administered by phone, and those scoring at least 10 (indicating some problems in at least 5 areas) were eligible to participate."

This study recruited participants with MS who had subjective cognitive concerns, as measured by a screening questionnaire. The criteria appear to align with real-world eligibility for an intervention targeting cognitive impairment in MS patients.

Quotes:
1) "Participants were recruited via physician referral, targeted mailings to persons with MS on the mailing list of the National MS Society, contact with support groups, and notices in MS newsletters and web sites." 
2) "The 347 persons who were initially screened as “eligible” were later contacted by phone to invite their participation during specific dates."

Participants were recruited through routine clinical and community channels like physician referral and MS support groups. This pragmatic approach mirrors how patients would find out about and be recruited to cognitive therapy in routine practice. 

Score: [4]

# Setting

Quote: "Following approval by the Institutional Review Board for the University of Texas at Austin, participants were recruited from three large metropolitan communities in Texas: Houston, San Antonio and Dallas."

The study was conducted at multiple sites in the community setting, not restricted to specialized trial or academic centers. This matches the setting where cognitive therapy would normally be delivered.

Score: [4]

# Organization 

Quote: "The MAPSS-MS intervention aims to help persons with MS acquire the highest level of cognitive functioning and functional independence. The intervention includes group sessions (2 h per week for 8 weeks) focused on building efficacy for use of cognitive strategies and a home-based computer training program (45 min three times per week)."

The intervention was delivered through a feasible model involving limited group and individual sessions. It did not require substantially more resources or expertise than would be available in routine care.

Score: [4]

# Flexibility (delivery)

Quotes:
1) "Based on the integration of Bandura’s self-efficacy theory20 with the investigators’ prior intervention studies,21,22 the program’s conceptual model proposes accurate knowledge of cognitive problems, lifestyle adjustments (sleep, stress management, physical activity) that support cognitive functioning, and self-efficacy to manage cognitive challenges will support persons with MS in the use of compensatory cognitive strategies and cognitive skills."
2) "The first four sessions focused on common cognitive problems experienced with MS (attention and processing speed, memory and language, visuospatial and executive functioning) and development of relevant compensatory strategies. The group sessions covered a range of cognitive issues, compensatory strategies, and lifestyle recommendations. The delivery allowed flexibility in tailoring the content to participants' individual needs and priorities.

Quote: "Neuropsychological testing and questionnaire data were collected from all subjects at baseline, following completion of the intervention, and 3 and 6 months post-intervention."

The follow-up schedule involved only 3 post-intervention assessments over 6 months. It did not include more extensive follow-up than would occur in routine practice.

# Primary outcome  

Quote: "Persons with MS (N = 183) with cognitive concerns were randomly assigned to either the 8-week MAPSS-MS intervention or usual care plus freely available computer games. The primary outcomes of self-reported cognitive functioning, use of compensatory strategies, and objective cognitive tests are highly relevant to the daily lives of participants.

Quote: "Changes in study outcomes were analyzed using intention to treat methodology, ANOVA with repeated measures, and ANCOVA."

The use of intention-to-treat analysis mirrors how data would be analyzed in routine practice.
